--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Wenner <robert@p...> wrote:

> Right now means during development / debugging, right?
> Looks like you are playing around and getting familiar with Toplink?
> 
> > I mean I want to elevate my test artifacts from workspacewindow
> > snippets to code which is managed by the version control system 
(Envy etc), available to team members, etc. And yes for automated 
testing eventually.

>Right now means during development / debugging, right?
>In fact you are debugging or developing, not testing or doing TDD?
>Looks like you are playing around and getting familiar with Toplink?
> Maybe you could turn those things you found out into automated test 
> cases?

Yes exactly. Right now means development/debugging but of course that 
means testing too. [Aside, in smalltalk, for many years, I have been 
writing small test cases right inside the method body as a 
comment 'during' writing of the method. This took the place of 
writing workspace tests. I could unit test the method I just wrote, 
and six months later it serves as a handy mini-doc on how that code 
works. This made a lot of sense in st where you can swipe and 
evaluate the code right in the method pane but that doesnt work in 
Java IDEs so it doesnt translate as well].

My persistence objects are currently quite unstable. So an 
interesting automated test is whether the code completes without 
throwing an exception. So, my unit tests DO assert something - that 
the code doesnt crash.

As things stabilise that will become a boring test (only for 
regression test a framework change). But at this point, those test 
methods would serve double-duty for my purposes if they could return 
a value.

Eventually I will add junit tests which will assert the findings that 
are now just explorations and new code. (I'm aware that that might 
appear backwards to a test-first proponent, that's a whole nother 
debate. I am agnostic on whether I write the test before or 'during'. 
I think i am a 'test-during' proponent). 

But meanwhile, I am journalling (cataloging etc, this seems to be a 
sticking point) all my testing 'thoughts'. I expect to cull the test 
suite to a strong usable set as time goes on. So, one might say I am 
developing/debugging the test suite concurrent with app 
development/testing.
